Caption: Figure 1: Generation of a location fingerprint. (a) An RF receiver receives the RF signal at a location block. (b) the received signal data are parsed and preprocessed. (c) The sampled signal data are the potential features. (d) The location fingerprint is a subset of these collected features that is unique to this location block.
Figure 2: The four panels of our visual analytics system interface.
Table 1: Feature transformation for ranking version of PLP

Figure 3: Standard deviation view of a selected feature in the Data Variance Perspective that shows several temporally unstable blocks. One is in the kitchen area and two are in the rooms at the back of the house.
Figure 5: Selected block a1.0n is clearly closest to block b1.0n as shown in the Spatial Variance Perspective.

Figure 4: Features selected using automatic correlation-based fea- ture selection in the Test Classification Perspective. 21 features are selected in this view. N2-1 have misclassified two blocks in the lower left corner of the kitchen when used as the test dataset.
Figure 5: Selected block a1.0n is clearly closest to block b1.0n as shown in the Spatial Variance Perspective.

Figure 8: Minimal Euclidean distance view in the Spatial Variance Perspective that shows spatial variance. This set of features should not be selected for the location fingerprints if the two red blocks at the doorway is our area of interest.

Figure 7: (a) PLP ranking version classification results with selected features using N2-1 as test dataset. The overall classification accu- racy for the kitchen area is 97.44 percent. (b) PLP original real valued data classification results with selected features using N2-1 as test dataset. The overall classification accuracy for the kitchen area is 94.87 percent. However, the misclassified locations outside of the kitchen is far worse than the ranking version.
